name: k-d-sequence
description:
We'll call a sequence of integers a good k-d sequence if we can add to it at
most k numbers in such a way that after the sorting the sequence will be an
arithmetic progression with difference d. You got hold of some sequence a,
consisting of n integers. Your task is to find its longest contiguous
subsegment, such that it is a good k-d sequence. Input The first line contains
three space-separated integers n, k, d (1 ≤ n ≤ 2·10^5; 0 ≤ k ≤ 2·10^5; 0 ≤ d
≤ 10^9). The second line contains n space-separated integers: a1, a2, ..., an
( - 10^9 ≤ ai ≤ 10^9) — the actual sequence. Output Print two space-separated
integers l, r (1 ≤ l ≤ r ≤ n) show that sequence al, al + 1, ..., ar is the
longest subsegment that is a good k-d sequence. If there are multiple optimal
answers, print the one with the minimum value of l. Examples Input 6 1 2 4 3 2
8 6 2 Output 3 5 Note In the first test sample the answer is the subsegment
consisting of numbers 2, 8, 6 — after adding number 4 and sorting it becomes
sequence 2, 4, 6, 8 — the arithmetic progression with difference 2.
